description: From Middle English dich, from Old English dīċ (“trench, moat”) from Proto-Germanic *dīkaz (compare Swedish dike, Icelandic díki, West Frisian dyk (“dam”), Dutch dijk (“id.”), German Teich (“pond”)), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeygʷ- (“to stick, set up”) (compare Latin fīgō (“to affix, fasten”), Lithuanian diegti (“to prick; plant”), dýgsti (“to geminate, grow”)). Doublet of dike.

entries.meaning: A trench; a long, shallow indentation, as for irrigation or drainage.
examples: Digging ditches has long been considered one of the most demanding forms of manual labor.
The truck careered off the road into a ditch.

entries.meaning: (Ireland) A raised bank of earth and the hedgerow on top.
examples: You flung a ditch on my vision
O stony grey soil of Monaghan
You burgled my bank of youth!

verbs.description: ditch (third-person singular simple present ditches, present participle ditching, simple past and past participle ditched)

examples: Once the sun came out we ditched our rain-gear and started a campfire.
Why did you ditch your last boyfriend? He was so nice to you.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, aviation) To deliberately crash-land an airplane on water.
examples: When the second engine failed, the pilot was forced to ditch; their last location was just south of the Azores.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To deliberately not attend classes; to play hookey.
examples: The truant officer caught Louise ditching with her friends, and her parents were forced to pay a fine.
Enclosure led to fuller winter employment in hedging and ditching.
The soldiers ditched the tent to prevent flooding.
The engine was ditched and turned on its side.

description: From earlier deche, from Middle English dechen, from Old English dēcan (“to smear, plaster, daub”). More at deech.

verbs.description: ditch (third-person singular simple present ditches, present participle ditching, simple past and past participle ditched)
